awd_titl_txt: Microscopic and Macroscopic Aspects of High Harmonic Generation
awd_abstract_narration:
Short pulses of coherent light in the extreme ultraviolet (XUV) spectral region can be used to investigate the ultrafast dynamics of atomic, molecular, and condensed-phase processes, which typically occur on the few-femtosecond time scale, and can be important in a wide range of scientific applications. A process known as high harmonic generation (HHG), resulting from the interaction between an intense laser pulse and a nonlinear medium, has proven to be a versatile source of such XUV light pulses. In this project, mechanisms underlying HHG will be studied through theoretical modeling and  calculations that consider both the microscopic and macroscopic laser-matter interactions. Some of these studies will characterize the properties of the XUV light generated by HHG, whereas other studies will probe the inherent dynamics of the strong-field interaction with the nonlinear medium. The majority of the work will be directly relevant to ongoing collaborations with several experimental groups in the US and abroad.

In the source development studies associated with this project, the LSU group will concentrate on characterizing and optimizing the HHG process from transparent crystals. It is only recently that such crystals have been shown to produce harmonics, and this has generated a lot of excitement due to the potential for increased yield and ease of manipulation of the generated light. However the mechanism by which harmonics are generated in condensed phase materials is still not well understood. In this part of the project, the group will expand on their current microscopic, quantum mechanical model for the laser-crystal interaction, which links the emitted light to the band structure of the crystal, as well as build a large-scale model describing the process of generation, propagation, and absorption of the XUV light in the macroscopic medium. In a separate part of this project, the LSU group will probe the dynamics of the strong-field laser-matter interaction itself, primarily through the investigation of HHG in the vicinity of excited states in atomic gases. In particular, a search will be conducted for signatures of these excited states in the spatial, temporal, and spectral properties of the emitted XUV light.

por.por_cntn:
When matter is exposed to intense, femtosecond laser pulses, it can respond in an extremely nonlinear manner by emitting light with new and higher frequencies, that are multiples of the frequency of the original driving field. This process is called high-order harmonic generation (HHG) and can occur for atoms and molecules in the gas phase as well as in the condensed phase. The emitted light is also laser-like and emitted in femtosecond or even sub-femtosecond bursts, and these characteristics have made HHG a widely used source of ultrafast extreme ultraviolet laser light over the past several decades. HHG has also emerged as a useful tool for spectroscopy of the generating material: the emitted radiation will exhibit characteristics that can be used to learn about the structure and the dynamics of the material itself. This project was centered around the calculation of HHG in two different classes of materials, namely (1) periodic (condensed-phase) crystals and (2) atoms in the gas phase. 

On project (1), we have developed several different approaches to calculating the HHG spectrum that can be useful either for quantitative calculations - for instance for comparing with experimental results - or qualitative calculations for an increased understanding of the generation process. As an example of the latter, we found that harmonics can be generated via so-called imperfect recollisions between electron-hole pairs that re-encounter each other after having been separated and accelerated by the strong laser field. An imperfect recollision is illustrated in the figure below. We have written multiple papers detailing our theoretical development and numerical results, including a recent Tutorial paper that will hopefully be of use to researchers just entering the field of HHG in condensed phase systems. We have also written several papers in collaboration with experimental groups.

On project (2) we have also been part of several experimental collaborations, often with the aim of optimizing the HHG emission from a gas of atoms in some way; either its yield or some subset of its coherence properties.

This project also led to the development of human resources through the training of the next generation of scientists. Two undergraduate students and three postdocs have been associated with this project; with the majority of sub-project (1) being driven by one of these postdocs. Nine peer-reviewed papers have been published, with one additional paper under review, and a number of both invited and contributed conference talks and posters have been given, by the PI and by four out of the five junior researchers.
